section.title: Usage information
section.p: There are two types of footnotes: single-use footnote and use-by-reference footnote.

dlentry.dd: This is produced by a fn element that does not specify a value for the id attribute.
This is produced by a fn element that specifies a value for the id attribute. It must be used in conjunction with an xref element with type set to "fn."

section.p: To reference a footnote that is located in another topic, the conref mechanism is used.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: The two footnote types typically produce different types of output:

dlentry.dd: When rendered, a superscript symbol (numeral or character) is produced at the location of the fn element. The superscript symbol is hyperlinked to the content of the footnote, which is placed at the bottom of a PDF page or the end of an online article. The superscript symbol can be specified by the value of the callout attribute. When no callout value is specified, footnotes are typically numbered.

Nothing is rendered at the location of the fn element. The content of a use-by-reference footnote is only rendered when it is referenced by an xref with the type attribute set to "fn". If an xref with the type attribute set to "fn" is present, a superscript symbol is rendered at the location of the xref element. Unless conref is used, the fn and xref must be located in the same topic.

section.p: However, the details of footnote processing and formatting are implementation dependent. For example, a tool that renders DITA as PDF might lack support for the callout attribute, or footnotes might be collected as end notes for certain types of publications.

fig.title: Example of a single-use footnote
fig.p: The following code sample shows a single-use footnote. It contains a simple fn element, with no id or callout attribute.
fig.codeblock: The memory storage capacity of the computer is 2 GB<fn>A GB (gigabyte) is equal to 1000 million bytes</fn> with error correcting support.
fig.p: When rendered, typically a superscript symbol is placed at the location of the fn element; this superscript symbol is hyperlinked to the content of the fn, which is typically is placed at the bottom of a PDF page or the end of an online article. The type of symbol used is implementation specific.

The above code sample might produce output similar to the following:
The memory storage capacity of the computer is 2 GB1 with error correcting support.
......
1 A GB (gigabyte) is equal to 1000 million bytes
----- [bottom of page] -----------------------------------------------------------------

fig.title: Example of a single-use footnote with a callout attribute
fig.p: The following code sample shows a single-use footnote that uses a callout attribute:
fig.codeblock: The memory storage capacity of the computer is 2 GB<fn callout="#">A GB (gigabyte) is equal to 1000 million bytes</fn> with error correcting support.
fig.p: The rendered output is similar to that of the previous example, although processors that support it will render the footnote symbol as # (hashtag).

fig.title: Example of a use-by-reference footnote
fig.p: The following code sample shows use-by-reference footnotes. The fn elements have id attributes, and inline xref elements reference those fn elements:
fig.codeblock:
Fido Puss My llama ...

I like pets. At my house, I have a dog, a cat, and a llama.
fig.p:
The code sample might produce output similar to the following:
......
I like pets. At my house, I have a dog1, a cat2, and a llama3.
......
1Fido
2Puss
3My llama
----- [bottom of page] -----------------------------------------------------------------

fig.title: Example of a single-use footnotes that uses conref
fig.p: The following code sample shows footnotes stored in a shared topic (footnotes.dita):
fig.codeblock: <!-- Content from footnotes.dita --> <topic id="footnotes"> ... <fn id="strunk">Elements of Style</fn> <fn id="DQTI">Developing Quality Technical Information, 2nd edition</fn> ... </topic>
fig.p: To use those footnotes, authors conref them into the relevant topics:
fig.codeblock: See the online resource for more information about how to assess the quality of technical documentation ...

fig.title: Example of a use-by-reference footnote that uses conref
fig.p: The following code sample shows a use-by-reference footnote that uses conref:
fig.codeblock:
Evaluating documentation quality ... ...

See the online resource for more information about how to assess the quality of technical documentation ...

...
